questions.question: An anion is formed when a neutral atom:
options: Gains one or more valence electrons.
Loses one or more valence electrons.
Gains a proton in the nucleus.
Shares electrons with a metal atom.
questions.explanation: Adding negatively charged electrons to a neutral atom results in a net negative charge, creating an anion.

questions.question: Which group of elements is most likely to form anions?
questions.explanation: Nonmetals have high electronegativity and high electron affinity, making it easy for them to attract and gain electrons.

questions.question: What is the standard suffix added to the root name of an element to name a monoatomic anion?
questions.explanation: Monoatomic anions use the suffix '-ide', such as Oxide ($O^{2-}$), Chloride ($Cl^{-}$), and Nitride ($N^{3-}$).

questions.question: How does the radius of an anion compare to the radius of its parent atom?
options: The anion is smaller only for Halogens.
questions.explanation: Adding electrons increases electron-electron repulsion, causing the electron cloud to spread out and increase the radius.

questions.question: When a Fluorine atom ($F$) becomes a fluoride ion ($F^{-}$), it becomes isoelectronic with:
questions.explanation: Fluorine has 9 electrons; gaining 1 gives it 10, which is the same electron configuration as Neon.

questions.question: An atom of Oxygen (Group 16) will form an ion with what charge?
questions.explanation: Oxygen has 6 valence electrons and needs 2 more to complete its octet, resulting in a charge of $-2$.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct symbol and name for the ion formed by Nitrogen?
questions.explanation: Nitrogen is in Group 15 and gains 3 electrons to reach an octet, forming the Nitride ion.

questions.question: Why do Halogens (Group 17) typically form $1-$ ions?
options: They have 7 valence electrons and only need to gain 1 more.
They have 1 valence electron and lose it easily.
They have a full octet and are very stable.
They lose 7 electrons to reach the previous noble gas.
questions.explanation: With 7 valence electrons, gaining one is the most energetically efficient way to achieve a noble gas configuration.

questions.question: Which of these elements would form an anion with a $3-$ charge?
questions.explanation: Phosphorus is in Group 15 ($s^{2} p^{3}$) and needs 3 more electrons to fill its $p$ sublevel.

questions.question: The energy change associated with an atom gaining an electron is called:
questions.explanation: Electron affinity is the energy released or absorbed when an atom in the gaseous state acquires an electron.
